docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon, New York's most influential member of the House of Representatives, announced today that he would retire at the end of the year, delivering yet another blow to the state's stature in Congress. Mr. Solomon, a 10-term Republican who is chairman of the powerful Rules Committee, said his unexpected decision was made partly out of a desire to spend more time with his family, partly out of a desire to make more money and partly out of concerns about his health. He had prostate cancer surgery two years ago.

headline.main: Influential Congressman From New York Plans to Retire

docs.abstract: Representative Gerald B H Solomon, New York's most influential member of House of Representatives, announces that he will retire at end of year, delivering yet another blow to state's stature in Congress; Solomon, who is chairman of powerful rules committee, says his decision stems from desire to spend more time with his family; his career discussed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Health Care Financing Administration spends about $2 billion a year overseeing the $230 billion Medicare program, or only about 1 percent of revenues. By contrast, private insurers spend more than 10 percent on administration. Yet even while denying the agency the money it needs to do its job, Congress piles on new responsibilities. For this year, the agency will make do. But if it is to root out endemic fraud and waste, let alone begin to better monitor the quality of health care provided to its 40 million beneficiaries, it will need more money.
docs.abstract: Editorial criticizes Congress for cutting Health Care Financing Administration's budget while giving it new responsibilities (M)
docs.snippet: The Health Care Financing Administration spends about $2 billion a year overseeing the $230 billion Medicare program, or only about 1 percent of revenues. By contrast, private insurers spend more than 10 percent on administration. Yet even while...

docs.lead_paragraph: In preparation for an important offering of high-yield bonds, Oxford Health Plans yesterday reported its financial results for the first three months of 1998. While the results were better than the guesses of many Wall Street analysts, the company continues to lose money from operations. Without offering much detail about the quarter, the company reported a loss of $45.3 million, or 57 cents a fully diluted share, on sales of $1.2 billion. The deficit included an after-tax charge of $16.3 million, or 20 cents a share. In the first quarter a year ago, the company posted a profit of $34.4 million, or 42 cents a share.

headline.main: Oxford Health Plans Posts A Deficit of $45.3 Million

docs.abstract: Oxford Health Plans reports loss of $45.3 million on sales of $1.2 billion for first quarter of 1998; Oxford is preparing offering of high-yield bonds; chart (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: PSYCHOLOGISTS rarely think much about what makes people happy. They focus on what makes them sad, on what makes them anxious. That is why psychology journals have published 45,000 articles in the last 30 years on depression, but only 400 on joy. Joy is not covered by insurance, nor does it lead to tenure.

headline.main: Seeking a Focus on Joy In Field of Psychology

docs.abstract: Dr Martin E P Seligman, new president of American Psychological Assn, contends psychology has become too focused on pathology, or the disease model, with not enough emphasis on what makes people happy; is known for his work on optimism, pessimism, learned helplessness and motivation; wants to remind psychologists of normal people and issues of love, work and play; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Senate's Debate on NATO Shifts Into High Gear The Senate reopened the debate on the future of NATO. Supporters favor the expansion of the military alliance as a way to unite and stabilize Europe, but opponents argue that it will antagonize Russia and perhaps ignite a nuclear calamity. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: In an effort to save money, the Clinton Administration is slowing the payment of Medicare claims submitted by doctors, hospitals and other health care providers, according to Federal officials and Government documents. The Government has also ordered insurance companies that review and pay Medicare claims on behalf of the Government, to send fewer notices to beneficiaries and to make greater use of telephone voice mail to answer inquiries from doctors checking the status of unpaid claims.
docs.abstract: Clinton Administration slows payment of Medicare claims to save money; has also ordered insurance companies that review and pay such claims on its behalf to send fewer notices to beneficiaries and increase use of phone voice mail to answer queries from doctors checking status of unpaid claims; budget for reviewing and paying claims rose little in last few years, while claims soared; Medicare agency is also swamped with new duties (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Russia Reportedly Offers India Help on Missiles Russian scientists have been helping India for the past three years to build a sea-launched ballistic missile capable of carrying a nuclear warhead, Clinton Administration officials say. The work seems to violate Russia's 1993 agreement with the United States to stop helping any country develop missile technology, and demonstrates Russia's inability to control exports of missile technology, suggesting a wider pattern of proliferation, officials say. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In his essay on auto insurance reform (Soapbox, April 19), Michael Schottland stated that ''most people already have their own health insurance.'' In New Jersey, however, the number of residents without health insurance has risen steadily from 13.6 percent in 1994 to 15.5 percent in 1996.

headline.main: Individual Health Insurance Hard to Get in the State

docs.abstract: Janice M Cauwels letter responds to Michael Schottland's April 19 essay about availability of health insurance in New Jersey

docs.lead_paragraph: LAST week Reckson Associates Realty Corporation, a real estate investment trust based in Melville, L.I., closed on its purchase of almost one million square feet of office space to bring its total holdings in Westchester to 3.5 million square feet. It thus enhanced its position as one of two REIT's that together now control most of the major office portfolios in the county.

headline.main: In the Region/Westchester; Reckson Builds Role as Key Office-Market Player

docs.abstract: Reckson Associates Realty Corp has just closed on almost one million square feet more of office space in Westchester County, NY, bringing its total holdings in county to 3.5 million square feet and enhancing its position as one of two real estate investment trusts that together now control most of county's major office portfolios; Mack-Cali Realty Corp, other REIT, owns nearly 5 million square feet; photo (In the Region/Westchester) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Concern Among Jews Is Heightened as Scientists Deepen Gene Studies'' (news article, April 22): Those disposed to see a cloud in every silver lining have managed to cast doubt on research about the causes of and possible cures for genetic diseases prevalent among Ashkenazi Jews. There are good scientific reasons to focus on Ashkenazi Jews, given the long history of intermarriage. The research is conducted by responsible scientists, many Jewish themselves, under stringent ethical guidelines. There are no credible reports of misuse of the data.

headline.main: Jewish Gene Studies Pose No Threat

docs.abstract: Letter by Lois Waldman of American Jewish Congress says there are good scientific reasons for genetic research among Ashkenazi Jews; says studies are conducted under stringent ethical guidelines and should not give rise to fears about stigma
